number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Good atmosphere and a decent play, possibly even worth a couple of plays for people that might have missed something and want a different ending.  However, there is no real ending, just a recollection of your experiences and what you previously selected as being the truth, everything is interpretable - for better or worse - and while never being able to know everything does leave the game to linger in your mind a while, perhaps prompting a replay, ultimately feels a little lacking.  This is a very short game, which can be done in 45 mins even when exploring everything.  The intro of the game recommends 1 1/2 hours, but with the limited areas to explore and even accounting for getting lost a little, I really fail to see how so much time could be spent on one playthrough.Home has the feel of point and click adventure games (without the point and click), but is too shallow to really fit in this category, and as it can be finished quite quickly, can be consumed quite adequately via a Let's Play on youtube.  I ended up both watching a Let's Play and buying and playing the game myself, just to see if I can change the ending, and while choosing different options and exploring a bit more thoroughly, ended up with an extra couple of sentences in my ending.   I bought Home on a 99p sale, and feel this was a fair price for feeling like I'd done my best to get a different ending, and also to contribute to supporting the developer a little.The best thing about Home is the nostalgia that comes with playing it, reminding me of the games that first introduced the gameplay elements that Home uses, such as the slow opening of doors, and descending stairs like Resident Evil.  Home doesn't rely on Jump Scares or Gore in the same way as modern horror games tend to now.I just hope that Home inspires more classical suspense horror games.  To me no game comes close to capturing the depth and suspense from the first few Resident Evil games, and even in the 8 bit style of Home, I'd be happy if someone put in the time to give a really rich and deep suspense/survival horror game.Sadly, all the deep puzzle games of old, like Resident Evil, and Tomb Raider, have evolved into action games rather than puzzle games, and while I enjoyed the Tomb Raider reboot a lot, really miss the games that require some planning, and problem solving.  So here's hoping Home maybe inspires some in the future.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												In this game you guide your character through a very linear environment and occasionally make decisions. Depending on the decisions you make, the text based story changes (sometimes dramatically). Unfortunately you're the only character in the game: you never encounter another living person or any kind of scarey creature. So it's basically a "choose your own adventure" book dressed up in some 8-bit graphics. The graphics are nicely stylized, but since you'll only ever be walking around them they really don't do much for the game. The writing is poor and the plots available are on par with "choose your own" adventure books too.Skip this one and read a book instead. Even at half the asking price a used book will offer more choices to make and a more satisfying experience since you'll imagine what's happening instead of being dissappointed that it isn't shown in the game. Or skip this one and instead play a game that does horror or mystery well.

content:

												I've harbored so much hate for this game that I'm glad Steam finally decided to allow negative reviews just so I can warn people to stay away.I dragged my way through this game once and it was difficult to make it all the way to the end. The writing is just plain bad writing trying to pass itself off as too deep for some people to understand.The graphics are awful! I own & have played more than a few "retro-style" games and they were old school in style but you could tell that they were made recently. To me, these graphics just look cheap and a way for the Developers to cut corners while hiding behind a currently popular style.Even at its' low price point, I think it is a waste of money.All of this is only my opinion of course & there are folks who have played and enjoyed this game, but I would say if you're considering this go for something like "Lone Survivor" instead.

To me, these graphics just look cheap and a way for the Developers to cut corners while hiding behind a currently popular style.Even at its' low price point, I think it is a waste of money.All of this is only my opinion of course & there are folks who have played and enjoyed this game, but I would say if you're considering this go for something like "Lone Survivor" instead.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I should probably preface this by stating that I'm not really a big fan of horror media in general...But all the same I don't feel like Home really has all that much to offer. It tries to run solely on atmosphere, with story delivered through pages of text. I actually quite like this approach, allowing the player's imagination to really shape the story, but what plot DOES exist is sparse and ambiguous. It's supposed to be, but even so, that also makes it incredibly unsatisfying. The gameplay is just walking around, finding keys to open doors. With a bit more depth to that, combined with the atmosphere (which is admittedly pretty good) the game could have been really good. It's an interesting diversion for an hour or so if you can get it really cheap, but for the most part there are better games doing similar things.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												As an experiment in interactive narrative, Home is mildly intriguing; it succeeds, at times, in subtly handing storytelling agency over to the player. This it accomplishes through the power of suggestion. The player is confronted with persuasive, yet oftentimes conflicting information: a multitude of narrative threads leading to the illumination of the final mystery. Where Home fails is in that resolution; rather then offer the player a satisfying bookend to their personalized experience, it merely poses more questions on top of half-answered ones. The prose is passable, though familiar and spartan in metaphor; however, the host of jarring shifts in verb tense seem owed more to an amateurish command of English than any intentional obfuscation. Home is a case of the unusual medium being the message; it is all the more unfortunate, then, that the message offered here is not very compelling.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												"Home" is completely lacking in substance. Whereas games like "Thirty Flights of Loving" or "Gone Home" present stories which may not be immediately evident, stories you may have to work to uncover or contemplate to unravel, there is at least an understanding between the creator and their audience that a story exists."Home", on the other hand, is like a "Choose Your Own Adventure" book in which every page reads, "I dunno, make something up."We already have a game that does that. It's called your imagination, and it doesn't cost anything.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												A very interesting game.  Some may choose to argue over the definition of "game" here, but who cares?  The question you should REALLY be asking is "will I get something out of this?"  Do you like mysteries?  Do you like interactive fiction?  Do you like creepy atmosphere?  If you can answer yes to ANY of those, this game is probably for you.  What seals the deal for me is that the story actually changes depending on what you've seen and done in the game.  This is a technique I keep hoping will make it into AAA titles.Important to note, this is NOT a horror game.  While the atmosphere feels scary at times, the game never does anything to frighten the player.  If you are looking for a horror game, look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2012
												Home is an extremely short adventure game with a fairly interesting story and retro 8-bit graphics.  The writing is well done and the audio effects in particular really standout.  Unfortunately the Steam Overlay is not supported correctly, and screenshots taken in game will be reduced to a very small resolution.  Where Home disappoints however, is in it's length.  Based on the presentation of the game it appears that multiple playthroughs may yield slight twists in the storyline, but from start to finish the game can be completed in 45 minutes.  For the price, I think this is too short for a completion and I would caution other gamers to take note.  Unfortunately, this title is so short that I cannot give it a positive recommendation and  suggest that other gamers give it a pass.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												So.... Survival horror! I'll admit, I haven't played any games in this genre since Silent Hill was released on Playstation, and I wasn't too keen on the genre as a whole. Nothing has changed since those days, so I wasn't expecting too much when I decided to get a copy of Home.When I first played Home, I was left with a feeling of what I like to call ".... Really?" So I decided on a second playthrough, and that's when things got a little more interesting. The main hook for me was the pixels (always a winner for me.) Graphically the game is good, and the overall aesthetics are brilliant. The 2nd thing that caught me off guard was the "you decide the outcome" factor, again this adds to the replay factor and it was something I didn't know about (I should really read about these games before I try them.)What bothers me about Home is that everything is there, but it all just seems kind of obvious, at least plot wise. The atmosphere that the game is trying to portray is completely absent, and I really just didn't click with the game. I think Home deserves a couple of playthroughs before it's judged though, because it is trying, and it shows. If you like Survival horror or you want to get a hold of an interesting indie game then it's definitely worth looking into. I'll give Home a recommendation, but don't expect too much.

												Hmm... very torn about this game. But for a $3 game, it's a very good price for it.I do recommend this to those that may get easily spooked and new to horror games, as this is just a small taste of it but without the frosting on the cupcake. You're only getting a muffin, and those are good too!I don't recommend it to veteran horror gamers and fans as this would bore them quickly and feel they wasted their money, which isn't much.-----Check out more games I see that deserve more attention from my curator group:BluePaw's Underrated Games ListJoin and/or follow if you wish.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2012
												Let's get the flaws out of the way first: There are a few spelling errors and there is no save system at all. That means you have to start from the beginning and play to the end in one go each time. Given that you have to play it in one sitting, it's pretty short, but well worth the money because there is a very interesting story being told here. You get to make a lot of little choices throughout the whole thing, and they influence what story you are presented with. Because of that, a lot of different things can be interpreted from the story and there is no definite explanation for what's going on. That makes this game truly outstanding.So to summarize, it has a great story, GREAT atmosphere and suspense, and can be replayed for different experiences. I also really like its look. And it is very simple to play, so you can show this to all your non-gaming friends and family and they will enjoy it too. This was a very memorable experience, and worth way more than $3.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2013
												Home is a very simple and fun indie horror game that isn't scary in the usual sense. Its not graphics-intensive, and the gameplay isn't very intricate either. Its strengths, however, lie within its superb narrative and the sense of dread and foreboding that occur as you progress through. The objective of the story is to find your way home, after waking up in a house that isn't yours, while uncovering some disturbing and haunting secrets along the way. Its easily played through in at least a half-hour, but the replayability comes from multiple endings based on how much you explore and what choices you make with key items and events. There's a surprising amount of hate on this game, but to me, this seems likely because people are comparing it to something its not. Its not Slender, its not Amnesia, and its not intended to be. Go play those if you want a more intricate horror game, but Home holds its own as a title that brings something different and unique to the table.

												I'm all about 2D games and love all the indie stuff that comes out, but this seemed to go out of its wait to make bad 2D graphics - Double Dragon almost looks better graphics wise and on top of that there is so many graphic repeats where it would not have been much work to make a couple different kinds of bookshelves (for example).I don't know if I played it wrong and didn't figure it out right (though I don't have the interest to play it again even though it was short) I swear I had it figured out in the first 15 minutes of the game or so, but the ending didn't confirm that or not as if the game wanted to hide it from me or make my character truly dilusional in his role in the game.Further, the very subtle effects like music (there was a little only at the very end) are really effective even when they're simple... this could have been a lot better with more of that.In conclusion, I'm glad I played it, but there are too many negatives to me to recommend this to anyone. Despite that, I will be following this developers work and hope to see his future projects increase in quality.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2013
												An intriguing, slow, minimalist and moody horror game. You wake up in a strange house next to a body, you want to go home.At only an hour or so long you can play the game in a single sitting, which the game suggests. Whilst the game is linear (to be expected for an 'adventure' game) you actually have some amount of input in the final outcome. The clues you find and the way you choose to interpret them has some bearing on how the story ends.The interaction is fairly minimal, but it felt effective as I played, choosing whether or not to disturb a body, touch a murder weapon, peek into someones drawer or take a discarded photograph. The art style leaves the environments sketchy, with good use of sound and text building immersion. In fact, sound is a very key part of the game and heightens the experience considerably.Whilst the game is generally quite slow, the atmosphere is well achieved and there is a feeling of mystery and elements of dread throughout. You feel like you're stumbling over questions and possibly answers as you explore, gaining insight into what has happened.If you do commit to playing the game, do it one sitting, play it with headphones on, in the dark, as the game suggests. Interact with everything you can, watch for clues in the environment, listen carefully and try to piece the story together. At the end you'll shape the ending to reflect your take on the story.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2013
												Home начинается как каждый второй хоррор: мы просыпаемся в мрачном незнакомом доме, на полу лежит изувеченное тело, а в трясущихся руках — только фонарик. Что произошло и как он здесь оказался, наш герой, естественно, не помнит. Но уже через пятнадцать минут блуждания по пиксельным коридорам начинаешь замечать, что в привычной формуле что-то не так, ведь вокруг нет ни души. Предчувствие скорой беды, неизменно присутствующее в завязке любого ужастика, в Home растянуто до финальных титров.

												Home is an interesting adventure game that is well done and is in a similar vein as maniac mansion, with a horror/mystery twist. It is short on the initial playthrough, however, you can easily get more than one playthrough out of the game. All and all for 3 bucks, it is worth it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2013
												I began to play Home with little expectation...and was more than pleasantly surprised. This game is very inventive with the genre and really tests the limits of its minimalistic style. The horror is more psychological, and creeps up on you gradually. I love how cerebral the experience becomes, as opposed to a typical blood and gore, jumpscare kind of horror game. The game allows a lot of freedom, and every decision you make eventually has an effect on your character and his psyche. Unlike most games, where you HAVE to find a certain key to unlock a certain door to even move on...this game gives you choices. Sure, you can find the key and discover more secrets...but if you choose not to, other opportunities present itself. Essentially, you create your own story of what happened here in this mysterious situation. Your character actually tells you how they would feel about certain decisions and will react according to your choices, adding to the dilemma. You can really empathize with him, or you may even become suspicious of him...The narrative style is very atmospheric and well written, playing out like an engrossing book or well made horror film. My experience in the game was extremely grim, and it made me curious to start a new game and try again, to see what I could do differently. It was that good.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Not so much a game, as an exercise in coming up with your own story. Quite a novel idea, in that you actually tell the game what the story was, but if you make slightly unorthodox choices, then the story starts becoming a little incoherent. I can imagine this device being used well in a better game.The actual gameplay is close to non-existent, and fairly tedious: even with its short time I was a bit bored by the end and wanted it to finish. The atmosphere, initially spooky, soon palls. The writing is almost good, but not quite enough to maintain interest in what is essentially a choose your own adventure book with a soundtrack. Although calling it an adventure is perhaps overselling it!Having said that, if you get it as part of a bundle, I'd give it a runthrough just for the hell of it, but I can't honestly recommend spending money on it, even at its cheap price.

												Essentially a long drawn-out choose your own adventure, if you define adventure as traversing a more-or-less linear and unchanging world picking up arbitrary items.All actions the player can take make no difference to the story, except only changing the block of text you get to read at the end of the game.This is one of those indie games that set out to be symbolic and deep, but failed. YouTube™ Video: NO GOD! PLEASE NO!!! NOOOOOOOOOO 

			Views: 16,487,925		

			Funny Gaming Montages http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLcB3lYavTog5yoHRi0iOCnUfCTh9Vj4j2 NO GOD! Playlist http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLcB3lYavTog5eDC7uO5w5DK_cehEpGK0L The Office s5e8		

Now before you say, "This isn't a review, this is just a video lol". Imagine me as Steve Carell and the other person being Home. It's THAT bad. Home is a indie horror story made by Benjamin Rivers, and I can tell you by far, this is the worst horror game I have ever played. Imagine putting a "Then a skeleton pops out" anticreepypasta and making it into a game. It's not scary, the atmosphere didn't give me spooks, even when I was supposed to be scared, I wasn't. The plot is way too easy to figure out, game is incredibly short, and just a bad game. I have warned every single one of my friends to never get this.And I hope this will help you too from making a bad purchase. If you got 2.99 and want to spend it on something, please, for the love of god, don't buy this.

content:
Posted: January 8
												Some seem to be complaining about the convulted plotline, but honestly it's rather clear. The game relies on what you think happened and what actions you take, whether that be deciding to pick up an item or not or investigating certain paths or moving forward. Near the end especially is when what you think and say matters, as it will change how the game ends quite a bit. I've only played through once so far, but I definitely noticed certain items I ignored or alternate paths I could've taken and plan to come back to it and see what else I can uncover. Overall a great game with a creepy atmosphere and certainly a great value considering the low price tag.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												Home takes the simple “choose your own adventure” formula and twists it around to make something strangely intriguing.It allows you to shape your ending based on the decisions you had made in your play through. It’s not groundbreaking but for this particular game, its execution was marvelous. You would have to truly invest your attention to the game if you want the full effect of the game to work. Play it in the dark, alone and with headphones. It's worth the set-up.Be warned though, it is a fairly short 1 hour game but in fairness, it has a lot of replay value especially when you are trying to figure out the other endings. Don't let this little gem pass you by, give it the 1 hour chance!

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												If you're looking for a game that you can invest dozens of hours in, Home is probably not it. But if you're looking for a fun, short  mystery to solve, Home is for you! It was great to play a game that is more about interpreting the clues and less on gaming skills. I played the game twice within 2 hours and enjoyed that I got a different ending both times. I will likely play it a few more times and make different choices to see what will happen. I bought Home during the Steam holiday sale, which means I snapped it up for next to nothing so I could hardly say it wasn't worth my cash. Don't let the low-tech graphics fool you - there is a great story to be unravelled. (Or will it unravel you?)

content:
Posted: February 3, 2013
												GAME HIGHLIGHTS :1. Retro Pixel based Style, exploration mystery solving. 2. Amazing story. Multiple endings. Good for 3-4 gameplays.3.Somewhat Dynamic level generation. You find new stuff in each gameplayMY 2 CENTS:If you lovegames for their stories more then mindless shooting and violence. Go ahead and buy this... Leaves you in such an awesome hangover that would keep you thinking hours after you finish it.Here is something really awesome about this game, when it ends it doesn't tells you what happened finally and how all the things fit together. It asks you questions and you answer Yes or No. Effectively it is making you tell a story to yourself. and that is the absolute brilliance of this game.It just takes over an hour to finish the game, so you can play it multiple times without committing too much time. For a dollar a piece this is just a steal for having an out of the world experience in gaming.

Posted: April 6, 2014
												I hesitantly recommend this one - it has good points. I like the art style, the few jumps. the element of choices affecting the gameplay, and a lot of the puzzles and overall storyline really left me hungry for answers. I love that in a game! But by the end I felt deflated - I sort of get the lack of closure, but found it a little disappointing. Definitely a game with replay value, but only if curiosity pulls you more than the lack of substance. It felt a bit too floaty for me, with a lot of potential for more that just didn't deliver. Still a good game overall, a fairly enjoyable way to pass an hour, and it has left me eagerly awaiting  the upcoming new game by the same developer.

												I didn't expected this much "horror" when I bought this game - the creepiness kinda builds up with its ambient sounds and slightly disturbing sounds at times. The good thing is that It doesn't have any of those cheap scaring tricks. As you play, you will slowly learn more about the protagonist... and the story is what you think it is. It's interesting to read about how other players interpret the story and how different it is from mine - based on the different choices we made and the different things that we encounter. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Home is a weird game. Don't be mistaken by its "horror" label, it's nothing of the sorts. Just a creepy atmosphere, but there's nothing horrifying about it (except what it may make you imagine, which is good). The premise in essentially that you're a man who wakes up in an unknown house...seemingly with amnesia. From there, you look for clues wherever you go, and according to what you look at, and even pick up, the game gives you clues about what may be happening. This is awesome! Seriously, it makes you change up your ideas during the whole game! Even if you have an idea about what might have happening, your next action might very well change it completely. Or it might strengthen it. This leads to a lot of replayability, and many different ways to interpret the same story.It's great! And yet, it's also pretty bad. Why, you ask? Its core ideas are really great, and, most of its execution is as well. However, due to the many, many branching paths, it sometimes get confused, and manages to screw it up a bit, mostly at the end.My big complain comes from the lack of a warning about the actions you can't undo. Some paths you take don't let you go back, and don't tell you that either, which leads to imense frustration when you're like "Oh, I'll explore this room first, and then get back here..." Well, no. Sometimes, it simply assumes you chose to progress with the game through that room, and it leaves you thinking about that one area you skipped, since you're unable to go back. And there is no save system, so you can't just go back, unless you want to play it again, doing everything in the same way, changing your pathing choice.This made my second playthrough very frustrating towards the end, specially since I chose not to read the very important clue and the end, to explore the rest of the house, and then go read it. But it simply didn't let me. And that completely ruined the ending for me, it really did. I'll have to go through it again, from the very beginning, which is NOT a bad thing, if you want to try something different. In this case, I'll have to go through it in the same way, merely changing the ending.This issue aside, my views on it are mostly positive. Its minimalist sound and graphic design work really well, and I love the way the story is presented, really great work. This is a game that even if it's short (about 1hour and a half for playthrough), it leads to a few playthroughs, which makes it very worth your 2€.I would have appreciated some music and not just ambient sounds, but it's not a big issue. Try it out! It will not disappoint you (mostly, since you might get frustrated if you "miss" the ending you were aiming for, but that is easily fixed with another playthrough).I'm certainly playing it at least a third time, maybe a fourth. Also, it gives interesting insight into game design and a different way to approach story telling, even if it needs some refining. Enough ranting now. Buy it, it's damn worth it.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												this game is one i found equally parts nerve racking and interesting. the whole game is played completely alone as you travel home after a night of sleepwalking, only to discover several dead corpses. most of the game is wandering around eerily quiet buildings, finding peices of information about people you know and the situation your in. the best part of the game is that when you find this information around it lets you decide how you interpert it and so it lets you create your own story in this tiwsted night. it really does feel like someones always watching you and it gets you to jump at shadows often, even though at the end of the game you realize that there was no real threat throughout the whole thing, and thats the kind of atmosphere that i love, oppresively paranoid but hollowly lonely at the same time

content:
Posted: December 11, 2012
												The pixel art made me feel comfortable. The story depends on your actions: everything you've done in the current and previous areas seems to be taken into consideration when generating the next one. It's an awesome, one and a half hour build-up of questions, with some suspense, a couple of simple puizzles and one hell of a lot of possibilities. The tension builds-up all the way to the end... only to have it all blow up in your face. Turns out the game fails to take some decisions into consideration for the ending, and you get absolutely NO answers to anything, ever - you're left with even MORE questions. An awesome build-up to a horrible anti-climax. I've paid less than a dollar for it, so I sort of should've seen it coming. With that annoying bug and no ending, I don't think you'll like it. Not in it's current state.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2012
												I got this in a bundle and wasn't expecting a ton from it, but it turned out to be pretty good. What would otherwise be a fairly standard old school adventure/horror game (which at times telegraphs a bit obviously what's going to happen next) is saved by subverting a couple adventure game conventions. For one, instead of requiring you to collect every item and examine every pixel and "do ALL the things!" to progress, it gives you the option to deliberately NOT do/get things, which changes the dialog/story. It also has a mechanic for not only making plot decisions but allowing you to interpret the story in-game. It's flawed, but it's not a bad way to spend an hour.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2012
												Home is a psychological thriller where every decision you make from what things you inspect through to where you choose to explore add up to give you one of multiple endings. "The protagonist" is trying to find his way home, but as you lead the way as "the narrator", our main man finds out just how much trouble they're in.For a cheap game that lasts exactly an hour and a half as the developer claimed, it's amazingly effective. I played it after midnight in full darkness with headphones on as requested at the start of the game and it made it a very eerie playthrough. It'd be nowhere near as effective if I played it during the daytime, but I could probably have gotten away without the headphones given I've got a surround sound set up.It's not the perfect game because one of the endings basically is a cop-out, but the other endings are much better. But again because this is a cheap game clearly made by a solo indie developer, I can forgive the minor flaws. It's a good thriller.EDIT @ 2014-02-23:More than a year since my original review date, I have not played this game again. Buy this game when it's cheap for a thrill, but I add the additional warning that the replay value of this game is very low.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2013
												Home is a experimental horror game, and when they say "experimental," they mean it.  The narrative, while still falling into some of the more traditional tropes of the genre, throws the user a very mean curveball toward the end of the game, and I'm about to spoil the heck out of it, so turn away if you don't like spoilers.  Actually, I'm going to do the exact opposite of spoil the ending, because that is  the same thing the developers did.  The spoiler is that the game never spoils anything.  Nothing is ever revealed.  Was there a monster?  Was there a serial killer?  Were YOU the serial killer?  Did you kill your wife?  Did you even HAVE a wife?  Was it all in your head?  The games gimmick is that YOU, the user, get to figure out the story, and there is no wrong answer.  After the game is completed, you are prompted to go to the games website and input your own interpretation.  While a cute idea, it didn't really work for me, and took me out of the "scared" mindset.  That, on top of the fact that the game itself isn't that scary (You cannot actually die) made me really unimpressed with the game.  The gameplay was one-dimensional, and the story played out like a choose-your-own adventure novel.  I'm just not really sure that style of storytelling works in the horror genre.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2012
												Home is pretty neat! It's an atmospheric side-scrolling horror/adventure game. You can interact with a ton of stuff, and the things you see/touch influence the rest of your playthrough and the potential endings you can get. There are no enemies, but the game's fluctuating narrative should definitely keep you engaged. Oh, and it's only about two hours long, which is good, because this game is a straight shot - no saving. (That's why it says I've played this game for a good 24 hours - I went to work and ran errands during a playthrough.)It says you decide what happens, and that couldn't be truer. At the end of the game, you're left with your experiences - the things you picked up, the things you saw, the things you did - and you actually decide what you think happened (I pretended that absolutely nothing happened - it made so little sense that even the MC was confused, lol). There is a TON of replay value; almost every outcome you can think of is possible. I liked it!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2013
												Home is a great little horror/lite adventure game.  A play through only takes roughly 30-45 minutes but it's designed to be played 3-4 times to see how the story plays out each time.  A lot of the plot points are up for you to decide based on how you interperet the evidence you were able to find during the murder mystery.  The game is as much about what you clues you didn't find as to which ones you did.  There are plenty of points in the game where you will make one choice or forget to go back and check on something that you will want to revisit on subsequent play throughs.  The creepy atmosphere the developer was able to achieve was quite well done through sound, text, and pixels.  It is best to do each play through in one sitting, with the lights off and with headphones.  It was a really nice change of pace for an evening and I highly reccommend it for anyone looking for something a little different in between more time consuming games.  Also, it is super cheap so the short length shouldn't be a deterent to anyone.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2013
												As of this writing, Home has been available to purchase on Steam for exactly one year. Yet typographical errors and bugs continue to plague this game. For instance, every locked door you come across triggers its "this door is locked" dialogue twice. Every. Single. Time. There is also one single part of the game where, after having used a gamepad for the entire journey, I was forced to use my keyboard. Quite confusing.The story comes of as a simplistic "choose your own adventure" format. Home is comparable to a 2D, side-scrolling Dear Esther, except you also have a very basic inventory system and the sound design is severely lacking.Even though it was somewhat enjoyable, I can not recommend Home to anyone knowing what I do now. Buying Home determines whether or not you reward lazy and incompetent game design.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												A 2D walking simulator where absolutely nothing scary happens. You walk to the left, sometimes to the right, open doors, and press A next to things with a white box around them.Everything you examine and/or pick up is presented as some kind of "clue" that potentially explains some aspect of the aftermath in which you now find yourself, so for the whole game it seems like you are piecing together some kind of mystery. Usually in a mystery game you put together all of the clues and evidence and ultimately conclude what happened. But HOME just shows you a series of items in a sequence and then asks, "What do YOU think explains this item? A or B?" There is no way to honestly know the answer one way or the other, so you just pick one at random. It really doesn't matter what you pick, because the game just says, "That is an interesting theory.The end."REALLY?The game is essentially a 50-minute long opinion survey about itself. It takes a sharp turn away from being a pretentious indie game and instead veers headlong in the direction of being an oddly narcissistic one. Can a game be narcissistic? I wouldn't have thought so, but HOME has made a persuasive argument that it can.Also, there was a point in the game where the controller vibrated non-stop for ten straight minutes for no apparent reason. I almost quit there just to maintain feeling in my hands.The only positive things I can really say about it are these:1) The game does have a pretty good atmosphere.2) It's an interesting narrative experiment, even if I personally consider it a failed one.

												Home is an interesting case. It's certainly not great, not even good, but as an experience, is worth a look. The game doesn't tell you where to go, there's no music, and has no other gameplay besides collecting different objects and simply looking around. It could have worked better if it was more psychological about it, by adding a monster to get you, but plays on the part of that says that there is something out there after you, even when you know there isn't. Your simply a child running away from the mystical boogeyman that trying to get you and don't know when. The environment and sounds are well-crafted and quite subtle. Pick it up if your looking for an inexpensive, tense experience, pick it up.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2013
												I feel like Home loses it's focus after a while. It's not a horror game as much as it just obfuscates the story and tries to create an eerie atmosphere that way. There are a few jump scares at the start, but those stop as well.The strength of it lies in how you find out more about the story solely through exploration. It's a neat approach, but the whole veil of "This may or may not have happened like this" at the end isn't executed well enough to have you ask questions. It feels more like it's cryptic for the sake of it.But it's cheap and takes about an hour to finish. I think if you want to see yet another approach at video game narrative, you should try it out. It's the kind of flawed game that's useful to play.Also, it's not pretentious like say LIMBO. It just stumbles along the way.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7
												I usually give games a few days of play before reviewing them. But I think I've seen enough. Home is an 8-bit looking pixel horror adventure game. It pretty much operates like all the old point and click acventures of old. It tells you on boot to turn out all the lights...and put on headphones. Fair enough. I do agree that games which favor spookiness need to be played in a certain way...at a certain time. This one does it so it can clip-clop loud footsteps and doorcreaks at you. Pretty much insistently and annoyingly. It does so so in-your-face that when you click on a door to move through it it shows you a pixelated door opening in full screen with accompanying LOUD door creak. Same with going up and down stairs. That...really...makes me laugh after awhile. But not funny haha. Funny as in...I can't believe they thought this worked. You start off in mystery house during a rainstorm without knowing how you got there. You do the same point and click searching and picking up and using things you always do in these. But nothing happens. Nothing is scary. In the occasional room there is a noise, a slamming, mysterious whisper but at this point I don't really read it as having anything to do with the story or the game itself. But more oooooo dev is trying to scare me with spooky sounds. Not thrilled by the puzzles thus far. And really not thrilled that once I got past a certain part, it won't let me go back and check out a door that I missed. Isn't a big point of adventure games that they are freeflowing? YOu can go visit and explore places? Read their descriptions? Enjoy the atmosphere? Well here is another fact of this game. It has laughable bugs. When I got bored I saved the game. WHen I started it up again and hit continue...TWO of me were on the screen. That's right. My character (the protagonist) is on the screen normally but since I restarted it had two copies of it. Once I went into the next room it went away. So like I already was thinking this didn't have someone helping with content. NOw I know it didn't have anyone testing it either. The story is what could have saved this. Events could have saved this. But neither have occurred.Edit: I've now finished the game...one run thru of it. I have to correct myself. The save bug does NOT go away. It is revealed when you use the mouse to move. You will always have two of yourself walking around the room once you restart. Now let's talk about the writing. Let's just drop this logic problem...At the beginning...you are trying to get out of the house. You come to a front door and...you can't leave...because there is furniture stacked in front of it! Why can't you just move the furniture like everyone else would do? There are lots of things like this. Also this game is written as if it was written in the past. This gimmick does not work. At all. It makes the game seems wishy washy. Makes it seem like nothing you do matters and that you aren't really trying to solve anything. Which I guess you aren't. It is telling the story and whatever you do is fine. That's the story. So there is no emotional impact for anything at all since you take it where you want. Someone also mentioned the achievements. Yes...the achievements also make no sense. And many bits at the end don't really make sense either. This needed so much more polish. It really is a grind.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												Simply chilling and thrilling, Home is a pixel horror that is not about running away from monsters, but doing so in your head. It is a mental game with many puzzles and although called a walking simulator, it is much, much more...Grapics- 8/10 Why so high you might ask? Well the atmosphere of the game is great and it ties in with the graphics.Controls-10/10 Simple. Easy.Handling- 9/10 You can feel yourself in the characters shoes.Story- 3/10 Not much here. If there was more meat on the bone I would have loved it but i cant say I knew what was going on at one or two points, basicly you are just trying to get home at night.Gameplay- 9/10 The reason for this being so high is that your character will have thoughts about your choices, and not even major ones. If you take the gun he is scaired because he think he will kill himself, or drop it/give away his position, etc.Creativity- 8/10 Done before but never like this.Price-10/10Hype-10/10 Better that expected.Overall- 8/10 The choice is your's to make, but for real $3 bucks is like a gallon of gas, just buy it!

number of helpful: 1 of 16 people (6%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5
												While I had heard of Home, the "unique horror adventure" released by Benjamin Rivers in 2012, I hadn't played it until September 2016 (part of a Humble Bundle). Let's not mince words here, calling Home a "unique horror adventure" would be like calling Super Mario Bros. "an epic tale of a humble man that battles the forces of evil in the name of love", which is laughable. Homesucks as a game and sucks as interactive storytelling medium.From the start, it did not endear me to it by requesting I turn off the lights, use headphones, and play the game in one sitting. In fact, it seemed to imply that I had to play the game in one sitting, which would've annoyed me any further. But still, I felt annoyed it had the gall to tell me all that.Listen. You do not tell me how I play my games. If you have to tell me the lights off and use headphones to create an "atmosphere", you're doing it wrong. You can leave the lights on and the jump scares in FNAF and it can still scare the bejeezus out of you and I'm not missing out on anything.The pacing of the game plods along. Apparently you can't walk and hold the flashlight up at the same time, and the little guy you control moves extremely slowly with no run button in site. The latter is explained in-game as the main character ("Sweater Vest Guy") gets hurt and limps along, but unless Sweater Vest Guy has some sort of crippling neurological injury that disallows him to walk and hold the flashlight up at the same time, it's a horrible design and one of the things that harms the game.From the beginning, you can already guess that HE was the killer all along (and references to the character's job loss and alcohol-induced sleepwalking seem to support that), but there's also some sort of contradicting "death list" found in underground tunnels just to mess with your mind and introduce some further fake ambiguity, all of which leads nowhere.At the end of the game, Sweater Vest Guy will likely commit suicide (whether or not the player character really believes it was he who committed the murders) instead of offering a choice like running away or turning yourself into the police (there is a way to just "slip away", either by a complicated process of picking up and not picking up certain things...or by just quitting during the credits and continuing there). Not that such a choice had a lot of emotional impact. It's hard to feel sympathy for a goofy-looking ginger with two pixels for eyes and a sweater vest, but that only makes presentation even worse--I say the death of Sweater Vest Guy is meaningless based on the way he looks, but keep in mind I also was moved to tears during Final Fantasy VI, and that was sprite art as well.I don't know Benjamin Rivers. I have no idea if he's a pretentious hack or a halfway decent guy who made a game that I just didn't really like. But if I ever meet him in person or online and voice my displeasure about the game's poor "storyline", I would be irritated if he said something like, "But ambiguity is the NATURE of the game!" then I would tell him this: "If you introduce disparate plot threads and then refuse to wrap them up or try to connect them in a logical sense, then you are not a genius, you're just lazy." But to be fair, Ben Rivers never actually said that to my knowledge, so until I have it on record that he said this, then it's still 0-0, he still may be a pretentious hack, but he at least hasn't directly insulted my intelligence.If you have hopes for a good solid storyline, then forget it. Benjamin Rivers has a middle finger toward you if that's you're thing. I'm feeling charitable enough to say that it is okay enough for the 90 or so minutes it runs, but it was a time in my life when I was unemployed and played video games all day. I wouldn't waste time with it today, especially how slow the pacing is. Yeah, it's only $3 on Steam, but that's still far too much for what he's asking. Your money is better spent elsewhere.

												Home is a game meant to be played in one sitting. It takes around an hour to complete (longer if you enjoy exploring every nook and cranny). number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 19, 2013
												I was surprised by this game. It started out as a bit of an underwhelming experience, where I felt like my choices weren't as impactful as I thought they might be. I thought that my "choices" were simply revealing more or less of the complete story as I went on. But it turns out, your choices *are* quite relevant, and become more and more impactful as the story progresses, to the point where you doubt and second guess yourself. The second guessing and uncertainty really helps build the suspense, and helps the player to develop their own questions. That's the beauty of this game. It's an experience designed not only for suspense, but for curiosity and doubt and fear, as one would expect for something of the genre. As a $3 hour to two hour experience, quite provocative, and quite enjoyable.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Okay, I'm going to give this game a reccomended thumbs up HOWEVER! It just barely does it for me.Spoilers!!! Maybe? Beware nonethelessWhile I didn't really find this game to be the horror-esque it claimed to be, I did find it was a nice quick play through that involved some exploration and a classic, choose your own adventure style. I had some trepedation at first, as always with games that claim to be horrors, wondering what kind of jump scares awaited me on the other side. Home offered no jump scares really... and as I played I found out my character, though he came across death multiple times, had no possible way of dying... so that was a disappointment at first... and although it let me take my time and start to explore a bit... it actually took away from the whole feel of it in the end.I went about exploring the first area entirely, the house with the dead man, trying to find what I could. I took some papers, left the gun... and found a video which I never really got to see the outcome of... I missed a point in the home where I could've viewed it I guess... but as the game progressed I found myself enjoying the exploration and the possibility of finding more clues as to why your character awoke where he did.The time flew by and before I knew it I was at the end. It was a very short game though but having bought it on sale for 75 cents I really can't complain.By the end I got to choose how I interpreted the clues I had stumbled upon, kicked myself for missing a few pieces of the story and found myself kinda, just a little bit... wanting to play it one more time just to see what kind of ending I could get the second round. However I have still yet to play it again and unless the mood really really REALLY strikes me to, I most likely won't.So, with that said...Story: 7/10I enjoyed it as I started to get into the game. I liked the choose your own adventure style of it and the whole mystery aspect. However I was very disappointed with the horror aspect the synopsis claimed this game to have. It left much to be desired.Replay Value: 5/10I might replay the game once more to figure out what I missed and what else I can get, but as for that I think this game would be retired from my shelf.Graphics: 5/10Wasn't much of a fan of the choice of graphics this time round. While the developer did a good job overall with his choice... I felt the game could've used more detail that doesn't come with the old pixel-style graphics. It left much to be desired.(Sale)Value: 6/10I mentioned I had bought this for 0.75 and I found that to be worth it. It gave me enough entertainment for the time the game lasted.(Full) Value: 1.5/10I wouldn't have bought this game had it been the full 2.99. Granted its only three bucks but seriously... I've seen much much MUCH better games go on sale on Steam for 5 bucks... and that 3 bucks would've been better invested towards those games.Ambiance/Music: 8/10This is what helped the game move along for me. Ambiance alone can help make or break a game so I applaude the developer in this aspect.Overall... out of 10... I would give this game a 5.5/10 good for the quick hour or two you may play it, but then shelf dust after that.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												Home is an interesting story. From the first moments when you wake up in an abandoned, derelict, house all through the rest of the game there is a definite feeling of being chased by something. The various choices your are offered in the game skew the game towards one of the multiple endings. The nice thing about a large number of the choices are that they are optional. Some areas, and thus options & backstory, of the game you can bypass completely simply by not exploring and taking the direct route.The game comes in at about an hour's game play per sitting, which some will find horrendously short but I found was about the right length for the story that was being told. As stated above the game has multiple endings depending on the choices made throughout the game so the replayablilty is good trying to get all the various endings.Overall, I enjoyed Home and the story that was being told.

												HOME is the story of man awaking alone in a house, not knowing how he got there and what happened.While trying to recover his memory he encounters strange places where some horrible things have happened.The story gradually unfolds by the choices you make which frees up some different insights he might have about the events you encounter. It's up to you how he remembers his life, what happened, why and how and what he did or not did and how it ends altogether when he finally reaches his home . . .Great suggestive atmosphere and a story that has an ending depending on the the choices/actions you made.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												A side scrolling mystery game where you wake up in a strange place, amidst strange circumstances, and must discover what has happened. With 'retro-styled graphics' and a simple interface, Home essentially lives and dies on its narrative and atmosphere.One of those is better than the other.Let's start with the atmosphere. Very little of the screen is visible, relying on your flashlight to illuminate your immediate surroundings. I think this works well, and helps build tension -- especially in new areas, or when the (sparse) sound effects kick in.At the beginning of each area, there's a moment of unease as we -- like our protagonist (?) -- don't quite understand what's happening. Unfortunately, the longer we spend in one place, the more the reused environments and lack of interaction exposes the threadbare locations. Honestly, each screen has maybe one thing to examine, or interact with, and the whole thing is stretched longer than it should be.That is the perfect segue back to the narrative. The mystery is pretty standard, and depending on what items you pick up, or how you answer the binary choices (Blablablabla. Yes or No?), things will change, but not nearly as much as I would like. Furthermore, some of the choices clearly align with the developers' intended canon, and others are likely to illicit a "Really?" response from gamers.To be frank, I would have preferred a smaller, more focused game with a dedicated narrative and more interaction (see Gone Home, or at least improve the branching paths like in Telltale's games). As it stands, it was an interesting experiment but not one I'll dwell on, or recommend.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												A very nicely designed, atmospheric game, easily worth the price of admission. An interesting, minimalist approach to the indie horror genre, in which the player's actions and perceptions directly craft the narrative. Allowing the story to be ambiguous permits the observer to fill in the blanks themselves, which might leave some feeling cheated, but which I think is a wonderful design choice if done well (and it's done quite well here). That's just my opinion -- individual responses may well differ, of course. I've played the game a few times now and have enjoyed each runthrough.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 5, 2012
												Home is what Dear Ester should have been, a dynamic narrative that can subtly change for each player. Unlike Dear Ester, Home is engaging. The closer you get to the end, the more tension builds in the game and in your own head, and your experience comes closer to mirroring that of the character you play. In Home, atmosphere is the star and it gets so thick you can cut it with a knife. It's one of the few horror games that really filled me with a sense of dread and unease as I moved cloister to the end. I had two issues, you can't save and one flawed puzzle at the end. The game is an hour or so long so I had to abandon my first attempt at about 30min in. One of the final puzzles requires an alt+tab out of the game to play an ARG or just google the answer, breaking the experience either way. Overall an excellent experience, double so given the low price of admission. Also, the developer seems cool, he answered my question about a mac version on twitter :P

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												This title is an absolute joy. I played and completed this game back a couple years ago but just recently played and beat it again. It's a great story. It's not for those who don't like slow games or games where you just basically walk around and investigate. Choices don't seem to matter but I've only played through twice. This game is very short, about an hour and a half. At the begginning of the game it tells you it's best to have headphones on and an hour and a half of free time to finish it in one sitting to get the full effect. This I absolutely recommend doing. With this game a lot is left up the the imagination of the player which I love but many people who need hand holding or have never enjoyed a good cliffhanger in a book do not appreciate. It is a great game for what it is and it has psychological elements although very subtle. The story feels slow but in fact isn't. The game itself is 1 1/2 hours. Depending on how you play and if you're a completionist or have to explore everything the pacing is basically based on how you play. I enjoyed this title and highly recommend. I mean, come on, $3 bucks. It's great.

												I finished playing this game about an hour ago and I'm still not sure what to think, although I am still thinking about it, which must be a good sign. The gameplay is simple but absorbing and the use of sound makes it one of the most atmospheric 8-bit games ever. It's just the ending... There are obviously multiple endings dictated by your choices throughout the game, it's just that the ending I 'chose' wasn't very satisfying. Knowing what I know now I could play again and choose a different ending, but I don't feel compelled to right away. That being said I can definitely see myself picking it up again in a few weeks/months and giving it another go.Overall it was a fun but slightly anti-climactic 90 minutes, with the potential for multiple play-throughs.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Badass little game we have here. . You pretty much wonder around looking at things to determine what events has happened recently. Blood, Letters/Notes, Dead People... What happened?   What is really neat about this game is that there is no True ending.  Based on your findings, YOU determine what happened in the story. There is more than one ending and there is no right or wrong ending.   You can also share yours and view what other folks interpretation of the story was.   Such an original game of its kind.  Pure Awesomeness.I have seen home go for as low as  $0.74 USD. This game is pretty short and does give you good material for what you pay.Rate: 8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												About half of any good horror story will be a mystery.  The best of those stories let the reader infer what has happened behind closed door, instead of directly stating it.  Usually, around the time readers piece together the puzzle to solve the mystery, they start to realize the picture they're putting together is about something terrifying.  "Home" realizes this, and capitalizes on it in a superb way.  It must be noted that this game is not for everyone.  There is no action present on screen, and there aren't even any enemies to fight directly.  Some people may not even want to classify it as a game in the traditional sense.  In fact, they may be right.  Among other things, this is a story that is being told, and the player takes the role of one of the story tellers.  The best horror stories let the reader infer what the author meant, allowing the individual reader to fill in the gaps with things that unnerve them specifically.  "Home" takes the next step by letting the 'reader' decide how their own interpretation of the past events will shape the future of the story.I recommend this game to those who enjoy a good slow-burn creepy story.  However, if you're looking to romp around and blast heads off of zombies, then this game will not satisfy you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												I received this game as a gift from another friend a while ago.  I never finished it the first time and I've switched computers since then, but I came back to Steam and decided to redownload it and give it a play.  This game has a very rich, complex story, and some events within it are obvious, while the rest of it leaves you to ponder.  I like the interaction you get within the game and your impending sense of "aloneness."  It makes for a spooky game you can get immersed into.  The sound effects are subtle, but creepy.  I think they work well with the pixel graphics, and a few of the noises legitimately made me jump (I'm easy to scare when I'm engrossed in these kinds of games, so it probably won't scare most other people.)  The game isn't a jump scare game like you might think or expect, though.  The story is what keeps you up thinking at night.My only complaint with this game, is that you don't get true closure in the end after you have supposedly "solved the mystery."  It leaves the ending open and squirming in your own mind.  I think some aspects are painfully obvious (i.e. the character had something to do with the killings in his temporary mental state, which he talks about.)  Some, on the other hand, don't give you full closure.  Why was he in the strange house?  (aside from it being necessary for the plot)  Who was the other man who had "killed his wife" and why was it important?  How long was the character unaware of the time frame in which all these events happened and he began to backtrack once he was awake?  Etc., etc.The game is great if you're looking for story driven.  It has an Amnesia feel to it in terms of the mystery of "what happened" although it might not have the solid answers you might be looking for in the end.  However, I do think the players who enjoy this will enjoy the overall mystery of the game as well as the mystery when the game is finished.  It's worth the one sitting play-through (which they do recommend you set time aside at the beginning to do.)

												I felt it was less of a horror game and more of a mystery game. Your choices can affect how the game changes for you. In the end you're left to think about what happened in the game and depending on the choices you made your take on the game will be different than other people. I think I enjoyed the open ending the best when I got to come up with my own take, and then see how other people thought about the events that happened in the game.I recommend this for those who enjoy coming up with scenarios or theories, but do not recommend it for those who want a set in stone story or who like closure for mysteries. This game starts as a mystery and definitely ends as one. The soundtrack and ambient noises of the game provide the sense of "horror" and sudden noises might give you jumps, but even for the most scared players this is at a level that is something that can be handled.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												key points for tl;dr:-Not strictly a game, rather a narrative-simply picking something up changes the story-vague do-the-math plot-not scary at allHome is an odd one. First thing to look for is the stupids calling it a walking simulator or more likely not knowing what the word "pretentious" means. Now, the way the narrative works is a sort of unspoken agreement between the developer and yourself; the yes/no question/answers leading to the maker putting words for the plot changes into your mouth. Largely, this fits okay, butsuddenly "realising" it's all a dream was a little odd. The open interpretation AND the choice to change the plot allows for a strange and dynamic relationship between the two is ultimately a fairly unique feature if one that's a little bit subtle to mention. It's certainly not lacking a plot despite how much some may say. This is not a game to play as a speedblitz or one to play to win. It's closer to Gone Home than most exploration/adverture games. Maybe not even a game, but there's nothing wrong with that. It is cheap as chips and pixel games are lovely to play, especially when they're in this style.The ultimate issue would be a slightly meh ending and not being scary. The odd sound is a little jump-rousing and the atmosphere is rather dank and uncomfortable but it is not scary. But neither are 90% of supposed horror games. There's also the attempt to give it replay value but if you play it No Stone Unturned on the first playthrough then the exploration element is largely done with.Oh, and there's no Vsync. It bugs me, anyway. Hey, it's £2 and not bad. Certainly a good first effort. Give it a go.

												It's a fascinating take on narrative.  That's the most I'm going to say to avoid spoiling anything.  Suffice to say, if the storytelling aspect of games carries any interest to you, this game's worth a shot.The game is very brief; it even states that it is best experienced by setting aside an hour and a half to complete it in one sitting.  Consider that as a factor before you buy.  I also don't expect much replay value due to the narrative system used; in fact, multiple playthroughs would more than likely detract from the overall experience, not enhance it.If, however, you don't care to play it, I have an experimental playthrough below.  It _will_ spoil the game, however, so it is absolutely not recommended to view more than 5-10 minutes unless you plan on skipping the game.


YouTube™ Video: Home: A Unique Horror Adventure Playthrough

												This title is an absolute joy. I played and completed this game back a couple years ago but just recently played and beat it again. It's a great story. It's not for those who don't like slow games or games where you just basically walk around and investigate. Choices don't seem to matter but I've only played through twice. This game is very short, about an hour and a half. At the begginning of the game it tells you it's best to have headphones on and an hour and a half of free time to finish it in one sitting to get the full effect. This I absolutely recommend doing. With this game a lot is left up the the imagination of the player which I love but many people who need hand holding or have never enjoyed a good cliffhanger in a book do not appreciate. It is a great game for what it is and it has psychological elements although very subtle. The story feels slow but in fact isn't. The game itself is 1 1/2 hours. Depending on how you play and if you're a completionist or have to explore everything the pacing is basically based on how you play. I enjoyed this title and highly recommend. I mean, come on, $3 bucks. It's great.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Home is a 2D Horror Game that proves you do not need realism in a horror game to have it be terrifying. You see, Home works on the same principle that many early horror movies did: Horror becomes more horrifying when you cannot see the threat. When it lingers around the outskirts of your vision, when you feel surrounded by darkness and evil, but it never actually steps in to harm you.This game is an example of atmosphere done right.Its controls are simple, its gameplay is easy to understand (if you're stuck, just go do everything that you can Interact with, that you haven't done yet) and there are branching story choices that for some people will dramatically change their interpretation of the game's ending.I warn you, this is some dark, dark stuff - especially as you near the game's conclusion. Home preys upon the pitch-blackness within your own imagination.Above all, its strengths are Atmosphere and a Staggered Breadcrumb plot. You will not find revolutionary gameplay here - this is a game whose gameplay serves its story and atmosphere, not the other way around. It is very cheap, and it should be experienced. You'll probably have a better time than with many more expensive games.Home is a bite-sized look at Atmospheric Horror that'll stay with you for a while; and you'll probably want to recommend it to your friends too - if only to hear their interpretations of the ending.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												"Home: A Unique Horror Story", is a game that doesn't play off the standard definition of horror being something to scare you, but rather something to shock you. This is a game like no other game I've played before (keep in mind I don't play a lot of indie games) and I walked away from it pleased with the gaming expereince I had. I'm a gamer that loves rich stories, and while this is a short game, taking me only 2 hours to beat at a leisurely pace, it definitely succeeds in being a game with a story I won't forget. You're thrown into the story head first as you wake up at night in a strange house you don't remember entering, with a flashlight by your feet, and a throbbing pain in your head. You must find your way home, and as you do you discover more and more about your character and the life they live. What's really cool about this game is that the information you learn as you go along doesn't necessarily define the protaganist, but rather helps the player create an opinion of who they might be. Each player can interpret what is going on for themselves to create their own ideas of what is happening in the story and how it really ends, which I think is what makes this game really unique and fun. With classic pixelated graphics I feel this helps the gamer focus more on what's happening to them in their story rather then how the game looks, which I really liked. I did a full let's play of this game in only 4 episodes on my YouTube channel, so if you're unsure if this is the kinda game you wanna buy hop over to my videos here on Steam and give the first episode or two a look.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2013
												Home is alright, but nothing spectacular by any means.  A mystery is afoot, and you have to decide which clues are relevant, and which ones are not.  Choosing which items you pick up (or don't) decides the fate of the story.  There are multiple possibilites of how the conclusion is drawn, and there are no good or bad specific endings.  There is no way to die in the game, which eliminates a lot of tension as far as making mistakes go.  The low quality graphics also encourage one to exercise their imagination a bit.  The sounds do raise the tension quite a bit, so I have to recommend head phones for full effect.  The length of the game (play through) is supposed to be about 90 minutes, but my first run was 75 minutes, even with my need to deeply explore.  All in all, this is a great ghost story for casual gamers, but the hard core crowd won't be very wowed by this one.

												Badass little game we have here. . You pretty much wonder around looking at things to determine what events has happened recently. Blood, Letters/Notes, Dead People... What happened?   What is really neat about this game is that there is no True ending.  Based on your findings, YOU determine what happened in the story. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												About half of any good horror story will be a mystery.  The best of those stories let the reader infer what has happened behind closed door, instead of directly stating it.  Usually, around the time readers piece together the puzzle to solve the mystery, they start to realize the picture they're putting together is about something terrifying.  "Home" realizes this, and capitalizes on it in a superb way.  It must be noted that this game is not for everyone.  There is no action present on screen, and there aren't even any enemies to fight directly.  Some people may not even want to classify it as a game in the traditional sense.  In fact, they may be right.  Among other things, this is a story that is being told, and the player takes the role of one of the story tellers.  The best horror stories let the reader infer what the author meant, allowing the individual reader to fill in the gaps with things that unnerve them specifically.  "Home" takes the next step by letting the 'reader' decide how their own interpretation of the past events will shape the future of the story.I recommend this game to those who enjoy a good slow-burn creepy story.  However, if you're looking to romp around and blast heads off of zombies, then this game will not satisfy you.

This game starts as a mystery and definitely ends as one. The soundtrack and ambient noises of the game provide the sense of "horror" and sudden noises might give you jumps, but even for the most scared players this is at a level that is something that can be handled.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												If you know what you're getting into (lo-fi psychological narrative experiment, with adventure/horror elements), then this is a gem for $3.00. Especially since you can play through it multiple ways to arrive at different endings. It's a little like a "choose your own adventure" book, although there's a unique twist: because of the character's amnesia and unreliable memories, a lot of the choices aren't about actions or decisions, they're really interpretations of an ambiguous scenario. This is actually rather original and brilliant. Also, pretty neat how such a seemingly "simple" game tracks many minor decisions and discoveries and item pick-ups throughout a playthrough, then in the finale asks how you want to interpret it all.The mixed reviews I feel are mostly due to one reason only: people don't like to feel confused. The plot, however you choose to progress/interpret it, is kind of convoluted, and you will probably feel confused at different points (its ok). Important thing is, the game is not nonsensical. It would've been nicer if at the end, once everything is being rehashed and tied up and re-interpreted, if there was just a little bit more detail or clues provided by the game (especially re: how that "first man" could possibly fit in), if it was a little less the player's responsibility to figure it all out. Hope that's a fair critique, because I do understand what the developer was going for.Once you beat it, check out: http://homehorror.com/whathappened/whathappened.php. Major "spoilers."PS: I think I overlooked another reason this great game got mixed reviews. It was/is misrepresented. The top tags for this game are Horror and Adventure, whereas it would be better tagged as Story-Rich, or Story-Driven, and as a type of Interactive Fiction. The developer himself acknowledged he was inspired by the Visual Novel genre. Yet he also wanted to create a great deal of "hype" and player investment in the game and its universe, so he really stressed the "horror" element. Not that there aren't some nice scares and plenty of general spookiness/dread/unease throughout. But it all boils down to this: this game isn't about "horror" and it isn't about "adventure" ... It may not even be a "game," exactly - it's an experiment in narrative form, and it's about the fallability of memory, and fatally subjective interpretations of events. It all boils down to the final few questions where you're asked to decide what you/your protagonist believes went down. The "boss" in this "game" is basically your own mind/conscience, and, surprisingly, it can still kill you. 10/10 Would be confused/uncertain/delluded/quesy about my own actions again.
