number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												[WARNING] This review is basically a breakdown of my playthrough/experience of this game. Therefore, it's pretty lengthy and contains spoilers, but it's worth a read if you don't mind the amount of reading, I'm sure a good portion of people who have played this game already can relate to what's written below.After sitting untouched in my Steam Library for awhile, tonight I finally decided to give it a go. I wasn't really sure what to expect, but with lights out and headphones in, I booted the game up and began playing.As I wandered about the starting house, I already became pretty interested in the premise. Exploring your mysterious surroundings in search of clues in order to piece together a dark narrative brimming with secrecy and murder seemed right up my alley. I made sure to search every room, check things multiple times so I didn't miss a helpful piece of dialogue, and made sure I picked up anything I came across in case I needed it later. I couldn't wait to begin unraveling this story.Then, I left the house, and appropriately ended up in the sewers.From then on, the game started to fall apart for me. Once the character started dropping comments about the handgun and knife I picked up as I searched through the tunnels and sewers, it was pretty easy to figure out what was really going on. But I brushed those thoughts aside and pressed on hoping that something ahead would add a new piece to the puzzle that would make me completely rethink my theories up to this point.Then, after completing a few more areas, the tedium began to set in. I was disappointed with the lack of complexity, the only puzzles being turning a valve a few times until they opened or navigating a "maze" of pathways to find more clues. At this point the main character has already beaten the fact that everything seems oddly familiar over my head too many times for me to really question anything about the story anymore, which made me wonder why I was even bothering trying to find all of these different pieces of evidence. But there was one major problem I had that seemed to keep reoccurring throughout my playthrough:The game faltered between rewarding and punishing you for exploring. While some areas rewarded a little back-tracking with a new key item you found for some more narrative, others decided that your curiosity should cut you off from everything else. The biggest example of this was during my time in the old factory. After coming across a door with a card reader, I remembered a note in the first house cryptically mentioning a key card and locker, so I quickly searched the different floors until eventually I found the card. I hobbled back to the locked door, and opened it to find... a hole in the ground, which served as an exit. A little disappointed, I went to go see what switching on the power would do... but couldn't. The game had locked me in that room and forced me to leave. I felt rather cheated; I didn't see any reason why I shouldn't be allowed to go back.Yet I still played on, just hoping that I didn't miss out on anything important.And after picking through the shop, I finally arrived home. This was it. It was the moment I had been waiting for, the big reveal of this tragedy. I pretty much knew what was going to happen at this point, but a bit of intrigue sprung back up from the interest of seeing how all of my previous choices and the discoveries I made would impact the ending. It was a rocky trip to get here, but I was here now. I scavenged the entire house, picked up that crowbar and ran down to the basement, ripped down that wall and carefully approached the pile of rags. The main character was quite nervous now, bracing himself for the horror he was about to witness... but then, something unexpected happened.He asked me if Rachel was in there or not, with a simple Yes/No response.Well... I don't know game, you tell me. Did the game really just blatantly ask me to choose what happens? I didn't really know how to respond. I decided to spare him the shock and chose 'No', to which he passed out from confusion. Once he gets up, I notice a bunch of the items I came across on my journey here are now scattered about the house. I go to examine the objects... each one asking if a certain event happened or not. With each one I examined, I couldn't believe it. After all of that, I was basically choosing what actually happened. I left the house, he rambles on about the decisions I made a minute ago... and the mysteries that were never solved? He basically shrugs them off, then rolls the credits. I sat there watching for a few minutes before I closed out completely.Now, I get that I could play through the game again to get the full story. There were probably a few things that I was missing that might have revealed something more substantial to me. But after beating the game, all replay value plummeted to zero. The fact that every decision you make during the course of the game is basically meaningless once you get to the end and basically write the ending yourself makes the whole process seem pointless. It just feels like lazy writing to build up a narrative for the entirity of the game, only to pass the reins to the player and have them create the conclusion instead without much closure. The fact that replaying a game that only took me a little over an hour to complete seemed like way too much trouble and tedium speaks for itself.All in all, this is a game that shows a lot of promise, but falls flat on its face and delivers only a tiny fragment of what it could have been. I'm sure a lot of you have already purchased this game from a sale like I had. In that case, you might want to leave it sitting in your Library in purgatory like it probably already has been. If not, then I'd say you're probably better jamming those dollar bills into a vending machine for a snack or a drink rather than dropping them on this game.It'll take a little less time to get through it, but like this game you'll only use it once before tossing it aside.And at least it'll be satisfying from start to finish.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												I had bought this game in a bundle awhile back, and have finally gotten around to playing it.This game isn't entirely deserving of all the negative reviews that it has received, although this game does have its downfalls.Judging from the in-game instructions, this was made for the XBOX controller, and does work well with it, except during dialogue. The dialogue advancement is broken. It requires you to press down, and sometimes it will advance right away, while other times there is a long pause before it will recognize the down key. This can be bypassed by pressing the down key on the keyboard, but jumping back and forth from controller to keyboard breaks the immersion a good bit.This game is also fairly linear with simple puzzles - if you can call them puzzles - that consist of no more than "flip all switches in building to open locked door." Or in one case you flip all valves to drain some water in order to advance. The game instead focuses more on finding objects that tell more of an implied story, as the character tries to piece together what's happened and why he's where he is in the situation that he is in. It actually has a very Silent Hill feel to it, although, aside from a few dead bodies, you'll never encounter another person to talk to. And with its linearity, it only took me exactly an hour to have explored every single room in one play through.The story gives no definitive answers either, and at the end encourages you to visit the developer's website where you can write about your own theory of "what happened" - or rather, "who dunnit." This is a murder mystery, and it is a nice touch that the developer tried to include the player in the storytelling process, but if you're a seasoned horror fan like myself, you'll probably figure out "exactly" what's going on half way through - and on the website, it seems almost all the other players came to the same conclusions.Graphically and aurally, I really enjoyed this game. Kind of reminded me of an amalgamation of some old Commodore games I used to play, if they'd had a much wider color pallete. The use of the low contrast black with the digital grain was nice too; it gives the game that "camcorder" look. I was amazed to see how many people worked on this game, as nowadays games of this caliber tend to be made by much smaller teams, however it is apparent that  a lot of work went in to the backgrounds and sound production, so it's not too hard to see where all that manpower went.Overall, aside from the dialogue box problems, this game can be an enjoyable hour long diversion. However, $2.99 may be too steep for most wallets, considering other games available at this price point, so I'd recommend waiting for a sale. But $2.99 isn't an outrageous price though, although it does seem a little high ( .99 to $1.99 would be more like it!)

												If you know what you're getting into (lo-fi psychological narrative experiment, with adventure/horror elements), then this is a gem for $3.00. Especially since you can play through it multiple ways to arrive at different endings. It's a little like a "choose your own adventure" book, although there's a unique twist: because of the character's amnesia and unreliable memories, a lot of the choices aren't about actions or decisions, they're really interpretations of an ambiguous scenario. This is actually rather original and brilliant. Also, pretty neat how such a seemingly "simple" game tracks many minor decisions and discoveries and item pick-ups throughout a playthrough, then in the finale asks how you want to interpret it all.The mixed reviews I feel are mostly due to one reason only: people don't like to feel confused. The plot, however you choose to progress/interpret it, is kind of convoluted, and you will probably feel confused at different points (its ok). Important thing is, the game is not nonsensical. It would've been nicer if at the end, once everything is being rehashed and tied up and re-interpreted, if there was just a little bit more detail or clues provided by the game (especially re: how that "first man" could possibly fit in), if it was a little less the player's responsibility to figure it all out. Hope that's a fair critique, because I do understand what the developer was going for.Once you beat it, check out: http://homehorror.com/whathappened/whathappened.php. Major "spoilers."PS: I think I overlooked another reason this great game got mixed reviews. It was/is misrepresented. The top tags for this game are Horror and Adventure, whereas it would be better tagged as Story-Rich, or Story-Driven, and as a type of Interactive Fiction. The developer himself acknowledged he was inspired by the Visual Novel genre. Yet he also wanted to create a great deal of "hype" and player investment in the game and its universe, so he really stressed the "horror" element. Not that there aren't some nice scares and plenty of general spookiness/dread/unease throughout. But it all boils down to this: this game isn't about "horror" and it isn't about "adventure" ... It may not even be a "game," exactly - it's an experiment in narrative form, and it's about the fallability of memory, and fatally subjective interpretations of events. It all boils down to the final few questions where you're asked to decide what you/your protagonist believes went down. The "boss" in this "game" is basically your own mind/conscience, and, surprisingly, it can still kill you. 10/10 Would be confused/uncertain/delluded/quesy about my own actions again.

												This is one of those indie retro-horror games -- steam is full of them. This is definitely a game. Basically has decent atmosphere for what it is and takes about 1 hour to win... if you define winning as "What the hell just happened?" I played through twice, and the game's charm is that it records everything you choose and spells out a (ideally) different chilling outcome based on those choices. In one playthrough I thought my wife was cheating on me, but it turns out I never had a wife -- I was crazy. In my second playthrough a murderer killed my wife and coworker, but I never found out who it was. Neither ending was very satisfying. I wish I could give this a better review because I love raising awareness of good indies... but really, not much to say.

												This feels like the first draft of a good idea. There's a good core concept here, but it hasn't been polished enough to really feel finished. As a result the gameplay doesn't really create an effective story or experience of choice as the writing and mechanics haven't been adjusted and redone to fit each other. Instead the sequence of choices and the end result of your particular ending feel nonsensical and very disconnected. The game also needs an effective sense of rythm as well as a more concrete narrative framework of rising actions, climax, and resolution. As it is now it feels unfinished, clumsy, and thrown together but with a good idea beneath that. I feel the developer might be able to make something really interesting with more experience and time devoted to their next project.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 2, 2012
												Home is an atmospheric adventure game with a concept clever enough that it makes up for a derivative setting and plot (or, more accurately, possible plot): you make the decisions about what actually happened before the game begins.  It's a safe bet that Benjamin Rivers is a fan of psychological horror games like the Silent Hill series and films such as The Machinist, and players familiar with such material will find nothing to surprise them. But the somewhat unique freedom that Home grants players to determine the story's details makes at least one playthrough worthwhile, especially considering the quality of the game's script and the low price.

While I don't want to give away what type of horror game it is, all I will say is that the ambiance in the game is truely amazing and the pixel art platformer is a very unique take on this genre. I snagged this game for 98 cents on a sale and that seems well worth the money.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												I liked the game telling you about what you missed at the end of each section because it means you can play it again and have a clue of what you're looking for to make a change. Unfortunately that's the only thing I liked and have no intention of coming back to it.It describes itself as a horror game but the only horror comes from the occasional incredibly loud sound effect, knowing you'll have your volume way up because the rest of the game is super quiet. And the gameplay is too shallow to really make up for it. The camera is zoomed incredibly close to your character so you can't see more than 10ft ahead of you, every room of the game is as dark as the last, and you walk so slowly that even when you can unlock a previously locked door its hard to justify taking the time to go check it out. The worst part is that for such a simple game the controls are pretty bad. Using the keyboard you have to use wasd for movement, space to enter doors, up to raise your torch, down to scroll text, and Y/N whenever you find a new item. It would be so much more convenient if the button to raise your torch (nearly useless) could be used to enter doors and if you could hit left or right to pick an option. The mouse controls are a little better but not much because you're constantly accidentally raising your torch which roots you in place.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												It was okay. Maybe I just didn't make the right choices, but I didn't find this game particularly fun — I got pretty bored, to be honest. Nor did I find the ending satisfying, interesting, or impactful.I also didn't appreciate how they executed the choices that determine the details of the ending. Asking the player what to have the player character do is one thing. Asking the player what the results of those actions were, or what someone else did — which is what it started doing near the end — is something else entirely.There are many doorways and branching paths, so I got lost a lot, which wouldn't have been so bad if I'd been given the freedom to explore fully. But sometimes I would go through a certain door only to be told that I couldn't go back, or that the character didn't want to go back. That would have been nice to know before I went there, that way I could have gone back and explored the rest of the area. I understand that a story where your choices determine the ending is one where you will have to forego one path in order to take another, but I would have appreciated some warning before the game made those decisions for me. Otherwise I'm not really the one choosing what happens.The game did not make it clear when my actions had been effective. An example: Turning a valve. If it needed to be turned again, I'd expect the character to state this out loud, without my needing to examine the valve again. I don't think I've ever played a game where this wasn't the case. But in fact, it wasn't until I went where I was trying to make the water level descend and saw that it hadn't worked, then went back and examined the valve again, that the character told me that there was still water running through the pipe.Lastly, as I approached the end, the game made sure to make me regret my choices by bringing up things I could have done but didn't. It felt like the game was giving me the finger for not doing "the right thing", which feels unfair when the point of the game is creating your own journey. What's worse is that one of those things that I didn't do, was not because I didn't want to do it, but because I didn't realize at the time that I could do it. The game didn't make it particularly clear at the time that it was something I could do there, and I had been under the impression I had to find another place to do it. Nope, apparently not, and by the time I discovered this it was too late.But, I won't say you shouldn't play it. It's only $2.99, it's a nice time-waster whenever you have an hour or two to spare, you might like it better than I did, and I'm sure it might be fun to play it several times and see what other kinds of endings and details you can get. But I personally don't have much interest in doing so.P.S. The only technical gripes: 1) The cursor didn't disappear the entire time I was playing, which got pretty annoying. 2) The game doesn't tell you at the beginning that you quit by pressing Q. Esc did not work, so I had to use Cmd+Q. I thought this must be a bug, until I finished the game and it told me to quit by pressing Q. I guess I should have thought to try that, but the game also should have told me at the beginning. Not to mention they might want to consider having Esc also quit the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2012
												Despite how much Home markets itself as a horror game, it really isn't. Home is better described as a murder mystery adventure with a psychological thriller bent. Outside of the eery atmosphere and fake shocks sprinkled throughout, there isn't really much in the way of actual horror. Actually there isn't much in the way of actual Adventure gameplay either, most puzzles are easily solved by just looking through the environments for items to pick up while the game takes care of everything else. However, this isn't the point of Home. Home's selling point is that each playthrough (clocking in around 90 minutes) is different than the last, inviting players to play multiple times to dig into the mysterious narrative. At its best Home is an intriguing experiment in the flexibility of interactive fiction, but it outright denies investing players with actual gameplay. Home isn't a failed experiment by any means, it's worth a look for those interested in gaming as a means of storytelling, but those looking for skin-crawling horror or puzzling adventures need look elsewhere.

												This is one of those indie retro-horror games -- steam is full of them. This is definitely a game. Basically has decent atmosphere for what it is and takes about 1 hour to win... if you define winning as "What the hell just happened?" I played through twice, and the game's charm is that it records everything you choose and spells out a (ideally) different chilling outcome based on those choices. In one playthrough I thought my wife was cheating on me, but it turns out I never had a wife -- I was crazy. In my second playthrough a murderer killed my wife and coworker, but I never found out who it was. Neither ending was very satisfying. I wish I could give this a better review because I love raising awareness of good indies... but really, not much to say.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Not a bad game. It was a great concept with less than satisfying execution. This is a horror game that is designed with some very good elements of level design, music, art style, and atmosphere.However, the game at it's core is just a simplified point-and-click adventure.**SPOILERS**There is no true element of danger in any of part of the game. The only thing that possibly serves to hinder your progress are one-way doors that progress you through chapters(for lack of a better term). There are many optional clues to be found which keeps the player engaged and motivated to search everywhere. However, the ultimate downfall of the game is that NONE OF IT REALLY MATTERS. The ending of the game literally asks you to determine what happens at the end. Depending on your choices, the game retcons details and clues and the layout of your house in order to conform (mostly) to the conclusion you draw. But inconsistencies still exist, and no matter what permutation of choices you make, it still doesn't deliver a compelling or conclusive story. This game would be salvageable if the clues you found determined the ending rather than asking you to do it. It's an interesting experiment in storytelling to involve the reader in choosing the story path rather than the actions that should determine the story path... but in my opinion it is extremely unsatisfying. Please abandon this line of thinking and tell a story through the actions of the character you're attaching the player to rather than asking the player directly for input.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												This game is very unoriginal and feels like a rehash of Silent Hill 2.  The pixelized graphics are not an appealing style in this game's case - they only distract.  The writing is appalling.  "I could almost feel the notebook in my shirt pocket as I thought of if the names could have any meaning."  Encore, Shakespeare.  The same sentence could have been written "I wondered if the names in the notebook in my shirt pocket could have any meaning."  The past tense is broken, and sometimes "almost" broken, fairly frequently, as if the "storytelling" style was forced for no compelling reason.  Finally - black cats, murder, scary noises, glowing eyes in the dark (that serve no purpose and make the game feel like a haunted house attraction), oh and asinine writings on the wall - is that all you got?  I was expecting more - but this game for all its flaws is not even scary.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												This shouldn't be called horror, and that's its biggest mistake, if you ask me. For many, I suspect, horror involves more explicit terrifying elements than corpses and the shifting sounds of buildings. In this respect, this game is far more of a psychological thriller than it is a horror game. Perhaps, it might be said, this is one of the very few thriller titles to be found in games, since it makes the decision to exclude both combat and any direct enemy confrontations. As other reviews indicate, despite mentioning that you choose the ending, the absence of any indication of whether you truly confront the cause of all the events led them to disappointment.However, while I can understand this perspective, I think that the game stands up well enough on its own, with the interesting use of interaction with objects influencing the narrative, to get by with this. In fact, the very real recognition of your presence at certain points makes this an especially interesting title to me, whereas for others it seemed a copout. It wasn't the most graceful integration of the player's involvement, admittedly, but it was closer in tune to what I had hoped Deadly Premonition would do, if familiar with that title. Either way, for as cheap and short as it is, and for what seems to me very decent quality (sound design/writing/artistically), I'd say this title is a steal if you're interested in games that experiment with interactive narratives.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												"Home: A Unique Horror Story", is a game that doesn't play off the standard definition of horror being something to scare you, but rather something to shock you. This is a game like no other game I've played before (keep in mind I don't play a lot of indie games) and I walked away from it pleased with the gaming expereince I had. I'm a gamer that loves rich stories, and while this is a short game, taking me only 2 hours to beat at a leisurely pace, it definitely succeeds in being a game with a story I won't forget. You're thrown into the story head first as you wake up at night in a strange house you don't remember entering, with a flashlight by your feet, and a throbbing pain in your head. You must find your way home, and as you do you discover more and more about your character and the life they live. What's really cool about this game is that the information you learn as you go along doesn't necessarily define the protaganist, but rather helps the player create an opinion of who they might be. Each player can interpret what is going on for themselves to create their own ideas of what is happening in the story and how it really ends, which I think is what makes this game really unique and fun. With classic pixelated graphics I feel this helps the gamer focus more on what's happening to them in their story rather then how the game looks, which I really liked. I did a full let's play of this game in only 4 episodes on my YouTube channel, so if you're unsure if this is the kinda game you wanna buy hop over to my videos here on Steam and give the first episode or two a look.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Home is a 2D Horror Game that proves you do not need realism in a horror game to have it be terrifying. You see, Home works on the same principle that many early horror movies did: Horror becomes more horrifying when you cannot see the threat. When it lingers around the outskirts of your vision, when you feel surrounded by darkness and evil, but it never actually steps in to harm you.This game is an example of atmosphere done right.Its controls are simple, its gameplay is easy to understand (if you're stuck, just go do everything that you can Interact with, that you haven't done yet) and there are branching story choices that for some people will dramatically change their interpretation of the game's ending.I warn you, this is some dark, dark stuff - especially as you near the game's conclusion. Home preys upon the pitch-blackness within your own imagination.Above all, its strengths are Atmosphere and a Staggered Breadcrumb plot. You will not find revolutionary gameplay here - this is a game whose gameplay serves its story and atmosphere, not the other way around. It is very cheap, and it should be experienced. You'll probably have a better time than with many more expensive games.Home is a bite-sized look at Atmospheric Horror that'll stay with you for a while; and you'll probably want to recommend it to your friends too - if only to hear their interpretations of the ending.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2012
												Home is what Dear Ester should have been, a dynamic narrative that can subtly change for each player. Unlike Dear Ester, Home is engaging. The closer you get to the end, the more tension builds in the game and in your own head, and your experience comes closer to mirroring that of the character you play. In Home, atmosphere is the star and it gets so thick you can cut it with a knife. It's one of the few horror games that really filled me with a sense of dread and unease as I moved cloister to the end. I had two issues, you can't save and one flawed puzzle at the end. The game is an hour or so long so I had to abandon my first attempt at about 30min in. One of the final puzzles requires an alt+tab out of the game to play an ARG or just google the answer, breaking the experience either way. Overall an excellent experience, double so given the low price of admission. Also, the developer seems cool, he answered my question about a mac version on twitter :P

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												I liked the game telling you about what you missed at the end of each section because it means you can play it again and have a clue of what you're looking for to make a change. Unfortunately that's the only thing I liked and have no intention of coming back to it.It describes itself as a horror game but the only horror comes from the occasional incredibly loud sound effect, knowing you'll have your volume way up because the rest of the game is super quiet. And the gameplay is too shallow to really make up for it. The camera is zoomed incredibly close to your character so you can't see more than 10ft ahead of you, every room of the game is as dark as the last, and you walk so slowly that even when you can unlock a previously locked door its hard to justify taking the time to go check it out. The worst part is that for such a simple game the controls are pretty bad. Using the keyboard you have to use wasd for movement, space to enter doors, up to raise your torch, down to scroll text, and Y/N whenever you find a new item. It would be so much more convenient if the button to raise your torch (nearly useless) could be used to enter doors and if you could hit left or right to pick an option. The mouse controls are a little better but not much because you're constantly accidentally raising your torch which roots you in place.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												Respecting Your IntellectIs this game great? I'd answer that with, it's what you make of it. Most have played games that have multiple endings, and this one tries to have a story-line that jumps from the screen to your mind.What would be a short description of Home?A game that respects your intellect developed by an independent creator, that is a BIT weird and creepy, ahem, not the creator, the game. It shows creativity and atmosphere, but I'm not willing to play it multiple times; I take the ending I get with the choices I would've made had it been real life.If you lack an imaginative mind, which many games cater to these days, you will find the storyline isn't that deep. You NEED to use your imagination to fill the gaps. Games that are so dark you need to squint your eyes to make things out do not appeal to me. Short sequences yes; but the whole game no. If you take the advice on the opening screens, you will find the game is somewhat hard on the eyes.Nice sound effects and concept, but at the end I wasn't sure if I had finished the game. To put it mildly, throughout the entire game I was left wondering what it was all about.New things are good, and this game is GOOD. However, it needs bigger doses of strangeness, interaction with consequences, scary moments, and a decent voiceover (instead of all the text).If you're looking for a game with a big story you will be disappointed. If you're expecting a horror game you'll be horribly deluded. At first there's some fear but after 10 minutes the dial goes to zero. At the end I felt it was a game just to get me onto the designer's website. So although it is a nugget you'd be pleased to find, as you examine it closely you'll find it's not pure gold; at least not as pure as it could be.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												Home reminds me of the games I played on my uncle's computer as a kid back in the 80s and that isn't a bad thing. Back before games became all about high poly counts and over the top action, there was an elegance in their simplicity. Obviously this wasn't always the case. There were plenty of terrible games back then as well but there was something about the style of video games back then that made for a memorable experience. Much like a good mystery novel leaves you with more questions than answers and doesn't give away the entire story, the video games of my childhood were entertaining during play but often left you with plenty of things to ponder long afterward. You'd wonder about that one-off robot with one line of dialogue and where he came from. You'd lay awake in your bed trying to figure out if there were more secrets hidden in that dark cave you just finished passing through. Home feels like an homage to that era of gaming... an era where one's imagination was as much a part of the experience as the production itself.I'm not surprised to see a fair number of people giving Home negative reviews but I hope the developer doesn't take them to heart. I've read several of these negative critiques and to be perfectly honest the bulk of them simply have no appreciation for games that aren't multi-million dollar titles produced by teams numbering in the hundreds. These are the same folks who can't appreciate most indie films because they don't know how to process a movie that doesn't spoon feed them the plot between explosions. I don't fault them for it. They simply don't know any better. I tip my hat to you Benjamin Rivers. Well done. What we have here is a unique piece of retro-styled choose-your-own-adventure story telling and it is beautiful in its simplicity and originality.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												This game is very unoriginal and feels like a rehash of Silent Hill 2.  The pixelized graphics are not an appealing style in this game's case - they only distract.  The writing is appalling.  "I could almost feel the notebook in my shirt pocket as I thought of if the names could have any meaning."  Encore, Shakespeare.  The same sentence could have been written "I wondered if the names in the notebook in my shirt pocket could have any meaning."  The past tense is broken, and sometimes "almost" broken, fairly frequently, as if the "storytelling" style was forced for no compelling reason.  Finally - black cats, murder, scary noises, glowing eyes in the dark (that serve no purpose and make the game feel like a haunted house attraction), oh and asinine writings on the wall - is that all you got?  I was expecting more - but this game for all its flaws is not even scary.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												I liked the game telling you about what you missed at the end of each section because it means you can play it again and have a clue of what you're looking for to make a change. Unfortunately that's the only thing I liked and have no intention of coming back to it.It describes itself as a horror game but the only horror comes from the occasional incredibly loud sound effect, knowing you'll have your volume way up because the rest of the game is super quiet. And the gameplay is too shallow to really make up for it. The camera is zoomed incredibly close to your character so you can't see more than 10ft ahead of you, every room of the game is as dark as the last, and you walk so slowly that even when you can unlock a previously locked door its hard to justify taking the time to go check it out. The worst part is that for such a simple game the controls are pretty bad. Using the keyboard you have to use wasd for movement, space to enter doors, up to raise your torch, down to scroll text, and Y/N whenever you find a new item. It would be so much more convenient if the button to raise your torch (nearly useless) could be used to enter doors and if you could hit left or right to pick an option. The mouse controls are a little better but not much because you're constantly accidentally raising your torch which roots you in place.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												Respecting Your IntellectIs this game great? I'd answer that with, it's what you make of it. Most have played games that have multiple endings, and this one tries to have a story-line that jumps from the screen to your mind.What would be a short description of Home?A game that respects your intellect developed by an independent creator, that is a BIT weird and creepy, ahem, not the creator, the game. It shows creativity and atmosphere, but I'm not willing to play it multiple times; I take the ending I get with the choices I would've made had it been real life.If you lack an imaginative mind, which many games cater to these days, you will find the storyline isn't that deep. You NEED to use your imagination to fill the gaps. Games that are so dark you need to squint your eyes to make things out do not appeal to me. Short sequences yes; but the whole game no. If you take the advice on the opening screens, you will find the game is somewhat hard on the eyes.Nice sound effects and concept, but at the end I wasn't sure if I had finished the game. To put it mildly, throughout the entire game I was left wondering what it was all about.New things are good, and this game is GOOD. However, it needs bigger doses of strangeness, interaction with consequences, scary moments, and a decent voiceover (instead of all the text).If you're looking for a game with a big story you will be disappointed. If you're expecting a horror game you'll be horribly deluded. At first there's some fear but after 10 minutes the dial goes to zero. At the end I felt it was a game just to get me onto the designer's website. So although it is a nugget you'd be pleased to find, as you examine it closely you'll find it's not pure gold; at least not as pure as it could be.

Posted: July 1, 2016
												I've never been this scared by a game before.This masterpiece is not about stupid screamers and typical horror sounds, which make everyone annoyed.No, Home is about the atmosphere. The strong wish to discover every part of the epic storyline was desperately fighting with not the weaker constant feeling that something terrifying must happen the very next second during the whole game. To make matters worse, the low visibility because of the giant pixels make your imagination play a bad joke on you, which keeps you scared all the time.I was literally nailed to the screen, trembling, but eager to visit every single room and to read every single text, just because of how exciting they are.Anyways, so far I haven't seen a better way to spend one of your bucks on Steam!

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												I couldn\'t get in to this game much. I really did try to get in to this game. I shut the lights and possible distractions off and everything. It has some spooky atmosphere, but I was more conditioned by this game\'s disposition as a horror title rather than the atmosphere of the game itself. The light space you\'re confined to in a TV static-like darkness is pretty effective, and the ceiling\'s lack of visibility until you shine the flashlight upwards is an effective tool for creating paranoia, but you are never once actually required to look up at the ceiling from my experience. The story changes on your playthrough because of vague conditions and I have yet to figure it out. It is overall decent, but you really do need to play it several times over to fully understand what it\'s going for. Though, I got this game on sale for literally less than a dollar so I can not complain much I guess. This is a cautious recommendation.

content:
Posted: March 28
Product received for free
												While home is certainly an ambitious little project, I can't say that I enjoyed much about it. Billed as a "horror adventure," Home feels like an Edgar Allen Poe short story with minor interaction. This is a 2D game where you have very few actions: move, investigate objects, and chose Yes or No at some points. In that regard it feels more like a visual novel than a game, and that's where my problems stem from. The story itself might be a bit unique in the realm of gaming, but it feels like relatively generic territory for horror as a whole. The story feels somewhat predictable from its opening frames, taking away from the game's eerie mystery.My main problem here is the game's lack of tension, which is crucial in horror. Other than a few sound-trigger jump scares, nothing in here is particularly frightening. Part of that is due to how often the game is broken up by text pop-ups. Essentially, every few seconds you stop to read a text bubble, which stops the game from being too immersive. It's possible for text to be scary on its own, but it just feels like an interruption here that breaks up the flow of the game.From what I've seen, it looks like this game has a dedicated fanbase, so there's certainly an audience for it. But after my first play through, I felt no reason to fire it up again even though I hadn't fully solved the mystery. The thought of treading through the same pixelated rooms and hearing the same sound cues just to hopefully learn a bit more just seemed boring. Even at one hour, Home can feel like a chore to get through, and that's sort of the opposite of how effective horror operates.(I also want to point out a quick technical bug I experienced here, which negatively effected my experience. Every time I clicked 'Yes' or 'No' at a decision point, my character would get locked into walking whatever direction he was facing. I had to click to make him stop moving and regain control. A minor annoyance, but one that happened quite a lot over the course of 1 hour.)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Okay, I'm going to give this game a reccomended thumbs up HOWEVER! It just barely does it for me.Spoilers!!! Maybe? Beware nonethelessWhile I didn't really find this game to be the horror-esque it claimed to be, I did find it was a nice quick play through that involved some exploration and a classic, choose your own adventure style. I had some trepedation at first, as always with games that claim to be horrors, wondering what kind of jump scares awaited me on the other side. Home offered no jump scares really... and as I played I found out my character, though he came across death multiple times, had no possible way of dying... so that was a disappointment at first... and although it let me take my time and start to explore a bit... it actually took away from the whole feel of it in the end.I went about exploring the first area entirely, the house with the dead man, trying to find what I could. I took some papers, left the gun... and found a video which I never really got to see the outcome of... I missed a point in the home where I could've viewed it I guess... but as the game progressed I found myself enjoying the exploration and the possibility of finding more clues as to why your character awoke where he did.The time flew by and before I knew it I was at the end. It was a very short game though but having bought it on sale for 75 cents I really can't complain.By the end I got to choose how I interpreted the clues I had stumbled upon, kicked myself for missing a few pieces of the story and found myself kinda, just a little bit... wanting to play it one more time just to see what kind of ending I could get the second round. However I have still yet to play it again and unless the mood really really REALLY strikes me to, I most likely won't.So, with that said...Story: 7/10I enjoyed it as I started to get into the game. I liked the choose your own adventure style of it and the whole mystery aspect. However I was very disappointed with the horror aspect the synopsis claimed this game to have. It left much to be desired.Replay Value: 5/10I might replay the game once more to figure out what I missed and what else I can get, but as for that I think this game would be retired from my shelf.Graphics: 5/10Wasn't much of a fan of the choice of graphics this time round. While the developer did a good job overall with his choice... I felt the game could've used more detail that doesn't come with the old pixel-style graphics. It left much to be desired.(Sale)Value: 6/10I mentioned I had bought this for 0.75 and I found that to be worth it. It gave me enough entertainment for the time the game lasted.(Full) Value: 1.5/10I wouldn't have bought this game had it been the full 2.99. Granted its only three bucks but seriously... I've seen much much MUCH better games go on sale on Steam for 5 bucks... and that 3 bucks would've been better invested towards those games.Ambiance/Music: 8/10This is what helped the game move along for me. Ambiance alone can help make or break a game so I applaude the developer in this aspect.Overall... out of 10... I would give this game a 5.5/10 good for the quick hour or two you may play it, but then shelf dust after that.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												Home reminds me of the games I played on my uncle's computer as a kid back in the 80s and that isn't a bad thing. Back before games became all about high poly counts and over the top action, there was an elegance in their simplicity. Obviously this wasn't always the case. There were plenty of terrible games back then as well but there was something about the style of video games back then that made for a memorable experience. Much like a good mystery novel leaves you with more questions than answers and doesn't give away the entire story, the video games of my childhood were entertaining during play but often left you with plenty of things to ponder long afterward. You'd wonder about that one-off robot with one line of dialogue and where he came from. You'd lay awake in your bed trying to figure out if there were more secrets hidden in that dark cave you just finished passing through. Home feels like an homage to that era of gaming... an era where one's imagination was as much a part of the experience as the production itself.I'm not surprised to see a fair number of people giving Home negative reviews but I hope the developer doesn't take them to heart. I've read several of these negative critiques and to be perfectly honest the bulk of them simply have no appreciation for games that aren't multi-million dollar titles produced by teams numbering in the hundreds. These are the same folks who can't appreciate most indie films because they don't know how to process a movie that doesn't spoon feed them the plot between explosions. I don't fault them for it. They simply don't know any better. I tip my hat to you Benjamin Rivers. Well done. What we have here is a unique piece of retro-styled choose-your-own-adventure story telling and it is beautiful in its simplicity and originality.
